Agency: Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Description: Five companies in Washington have agreed to correct errors in reporting hazardous chemicals as required by federal laws designed to protect communities during chemical emergencies. The companies failed to report the storage of hazardous chemicals in violation of the Emergency Planning and Community-Right-to-Know Act, according to settlements with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The companies have agreed to correct the violations and pay fines.
Notes: Note: This penalty is a duplicate of an amount shown in another record (either because it applies to a multi-location settlement or because Violation Tracker contains an agency record and a settlement announcement for the same case).

Agency: Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration

Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Description: Targa agreed to pay a $150,000 civil penalty and pay at least $6,234,375 to fund Supplemental Environmental Projects in settlement of allegations it exceeded permitted emission limits at its Monument Gas Plant.
